in death, the trailblazing force behind the Pop Group remains an uncompromising firebrand.","full_text":"Even in death, Mark Stewart remains an uncompromising firebrand, raising a very singular sort of ruckus on his posthumous release, “The Fateful Symmetry”. Arriving two years after his passing, Stewart’s (presumably) final record is packed with a passion as intense as the feral abandon that filled his work with The Pop Group. But it bespeaks a maturity that channels his wild fury into subtler settings—a velvet hammer instead of a hydraulic piledriver.

With the aforementioned trailblazing Brits, Stewart helped define the post-punk era, incorporating funk, dub, and free jazz elements into a highly charged agitprop environment. Across a solo career that spanned some 40 years, he steadily expanded his palette, adding electronic and industrial flavors and anything else that suited his fancy. Along the way, his fearless forays into unexplored territory inspired a rogue’s gallery of iconoclasts, including Nick Cave, Trent Reznor, and Tricky.

The album Stewart was assembling towards the end of his life is a bit like a broken mirror—stylistic shards of his musical personality are strewn all about, but the identity of their bearer is still unmistakable. “Memory of You,” produced by Youth from Killing Joke, kicks things off by framing Stewart’s dramatic delivery with some propulsive synth pop. The slow-rolling “Neon Girl” bears a splash of the trip-hop sound that Stewart himself helped inspire, mated to a singalong chorus including Gina Birch of The Pop Group’s post-punk peers The Raincoats. And if piano-based ballads “This is the Rain” and “A Long Road” bring the more sedate side of Nick Cave to mind, it’s simply because Cave has absorbed so much of Stewart’s artistic DNA.

Perhaps the biggest surprise arrives when Stewart’s old cohort and UK dub pioneer Adrian Sherwood helps him mix an angsty take on the sleek, synth-flecked pop of The Korgis’s 1980 single “Everybody’s Got to Learn Sometime” with a haunting cumbia/dub sample from new-schooler Elijah Minelli. The result suggests what might have happened if Augustus Pablo had overseen an ‘80s John Hughes soundtrack.

Forceful tempos and overtly aggressive gambits are thin on the ground throughout the album. The four-on-the-floor beat and dense guitar riffing on “Blank Town” give “The Fateful Symmetry” its closest thing to a rocker. But Stewart’s emotional temperature is still akin to the one famously espoused by Tina Turner in the intro to her classic version of “Proud Mary,” when she declared, “We never ever do nothing nice and easy.” Subversive, capricious, and eternally unwilling to allow an inch of distance between himself and his audience—in all the ways that count, the man who says goodbye on “The Fateful Symmetry” is indistinguishable from the one we’ve known all along.

–Jim Allen","title":"Mark Stewart, “The Fateful Lisbon"}}],"audio_stream_url":null},{"story_id":185079,"story_date":1752153606,"slug":"slikback-attrition-review","description":"The legendary Kenyan producer’s Planet Mu debut offers an expansion of his musical palette.","full_text":"Slikback is tired of waiting around. There have been occasions where the Kenyan musician has been booked to play festivals, but missed out due to visa issues. So when it comes to his recorded music Slikback—aka Freddy Mwaura Njau— has come up with a solution: Don’t wait. Njau self-releases most of his music via Bandcamp, and last year compiled highlights from his recent handful of singles into one eponymous 22-track collection.

But exceptions are made for exceptional circumstances, like a debut full-length album for esteemed label Planet Mu. With “Attrition”, Njau stuck to Mu’s deadline, composing all of its tracks while waiting for yet another visa to come through in his new home of Poland. Experiments that Njau might have otherwise spread over a handful of self-released EPs are here melded into two, or even one, tune—deftly shapeshifting his belligerent techno into great abstract forms like a seasoned potter, repeatedly applying water to his clay.

The founding elements of “Attrition” are as uncompromising as the rest of Njau’s back catalogue: Hard drum compositions that sound as though they were forged from a Warhammer 40K armory. On “Sheltered,” deep, mechanoid percussion pummels the foreground in scattergun bursts, while the relentless slashing of hi-hats and screeching of radio static on “Knot” rival black metal’s blast beats and electric guitar squalls. Such immediacy and aggressiveness is precisely what Slikback fans keep coming back for. Few dance music producers make tunes as heady as the Hakuna Kulala co-founder.

But judging by the plethora of extreme dance floor music he’s produced, Njau can probably make heavy music in his sleep by now. Less familiar are the gentle ambient textures and flourishes of EDM he works into “Attrition” for more emotional depth. The long jet streams of sub bass undulating beneath upward string flurries lift “Duality” up to soaring, trance-y heights, while the chanting samples on “Fracture” are ritualistic. His work has often been oppressively great; here it can feel grand, melodramatic and foreboding.

Some tracks act like dramatic pauses before the chaos. “Snow” plonks playful mallet phrases beside sustained harpsichord synths that glow like street lamps in the fog. Though there’s something inherently romantic about the harpsichord, in the context of this record (i.e. just before the noise of “Knot”) that calm carries the same tension as the silence right before you turn a corner in Resident Evil. “Semblance of Composure”’s gliding pads are another moment of respite before the barrage on “Taped,” but it lacks the mercurial character of “Duality” and the sweetness of “Snow.”

The more restless Njau’s music the better—and the more it plays to his strengths. His warring percussion is founded on a spare base that’s akin to dubstep’s, and that frees the beat to behave more like a fly fishing rod, skimming the surface in irregular, sweeping patterns, rather than as an anchor tethered to the ocean floor. “Spend”’s rhythm bounces between 180 BPM takes on footwork and hardcore techno, at first hurrying two beats into the end of each triplet, before spurring into a gallop and then further roughing up footwork’s framework with quickfire volleys of kick drums and snares. Occasionally, a drum might land out of time—a misfire; rather than erase it, Njau relishes the mishaps.

“Attrition” isn’t just another exhibition of the Njau’s singular sound, it’s an affirmation that he can rewire his palette any which way he likes. He consciously integrates fresher, more romantic sounds into his framework and utilizes dub’s open form, along with ambient samples and EDM moods, to magnify the scale of his techno. “Attrition” is a landmark of a record from an artist with a sprawling, restive genius.
